Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.intro:
When you bring attention to good behaviours, your teen is likely to behave well more often and feel good about themselves!

Here are 4 simple tips for praising Your Teen:
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ *SEE IT*

ğŸ‘€ Look for anything good or helpful Your Teen does.

â¸ Pause and really notice when they are doing something positive.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ *SAY IT*

ğŸ† Praise them when you see them do something you like.

âœ… Tell them specifically what they have done well.

ğŸ‰ Be enthusiastic and really mean it!

ğŸ”„ This means they are more likely to do it again.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ *REPEAT IT*

ğŸŒ· Look for something to praise Your Teen for every day.

ğŸ”¶ Even if it is something really small, keep doing it.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.4.text:
4ï¸âƒ£ *KEEP IT POSITIVE*

ğŸ’¡ Make sure you focus on something your teen has done well.

ğŸ™‚You can show your praise with a big smile and words. You can also raise your thumb, hug, or wink an eye at Your Teen to show you appreciate them.

ğŸŒˆ Keeping it positive reminds your teen that you notice them and care.

To continue building a positive relationship with Your Teen, letâ€™s make one-on-one time a part of a routine. You can use the tips for one-on-one routines to create other daily routines with Your Teen. 

Creating other daily routines with Your Teen will also help them feel more secure, safe and cooperative. ğŸ”‘ Help them plan time for resting, meals, chores, school, and sleep. â°

Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.intro: Here are some tips on how to create routines with Your Teen.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ BE A TEAM
â˜• Talk to Your Teen about what they want their routines to look like.
âœ¨ Your Teen is more likely to follow routines when they help to set them.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ BE CONSISTENT
ğŸ‘€ Make sure Your Teen follows their routines daily.
ğŸ’™ This helps your teen feel safe and secure, because they know what to expect.
ğŸŒ± Feeling secure means Your Teen has space to grow, develop and gain independence.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ PRAISE, PRAISE, PRAISE
ğŸˆ Praise Your Teen for setting a routine with you.
ğŸŒˆ Praise Your Teen when they stick to it.

Improve My Relationship with My Teen.introduction.msg_list: This skill is about noticing your and Your Teen feelings during one-on-one time.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.importance.msg_list:
Noticing and Talking about feelings with Your Teen will help them learn how to express themselves. 

ğŸ‘ŒThey will learn that all feelings are okay - even the unpleasant ones.
 
ğŸŒ· You can help by listening to them, thinking about how it must feel for them, and accepting their emotions. 

ğŸ¤—This will help them recognise other peopleâ€™s feelings, too.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.quiz.content.1.question: True or False: Talking about pleasant feelings is not as important as sharing unpleasant feelings.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.quiz.content.1.feedback_correct: ğŸ‰ Thatâ€™s correct. There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Itâ€™s important that we talk with our teens about ALL of them.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.quiz.content.1.feedback_incorrect: ğŸ‘€Oops! Good Try!There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Itâ€™s important that we talk with our teens about ALL of them.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.quiz.content.2.question: Hereâ€™s another one: Boys should not share when they are feeling sad or afraid.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.quiz.content.2.feedback_correct: ğŸ‰ You are right! It is important that both boys and girls learn how to communicate about all of their feelings. Boys will learn that it is okay to feel upset or sad about something and that it is okay to ask for help when they need it.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.quiz.content.2.feedback_incorrect: ğŸ‘€ Oops! Good Try! It is important that both boys and girls learn how to communicate about all their feelings. Boys will learn that it is okay to feel upset or sad about something and that it is okay to ask for help when they need it. This is important for girls, too!
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.quiz.content.3.question: Last one: As parents, we can also share our feelings with our teens.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.quiz.content.3.feedback_correct: ğŸ‰ Correct! Sharing our own feelings with our teens in a calm way shows them how to do it themselves.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.quiz.content.3.feedback_incorrect: ğŸ‘€ Oops! Good Try! Sharing your own feelings with your teen in a calm way shows them how to do it themselves.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.comic.intro: Here is a comic about how you can talk about feelings with your teen during one-on-one time.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.comic.text.1: {F1_FATHER} and {F1_DAUGHTER_16} are spending one-on-one time by taking a walk together. {F1_DAUGHTER_16} looks very upset.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.comic.text.2:
{F1_FATHER}: {F1_DAUGHTER_16}, I noticed you have less energy today and you look sad. Do you want to talk about it? 
{F1_DAUGHTER_16}: Oh, Dad. I just find it so sad and frustrating that I studied so hard for my maths test and failed.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.comic.text.3:
{F1_FATHER}: That is frustrating, my girl. I know how hard you studied. Maybe we can come up with a new plan to help you with maths. How about we ask your teacher for extra help? Would you like me to talk to her or do you want to do it? 
{F1_DAUGHTER_16}: Thank you, dad. I can do it! I think that might be a good idea.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.comic.text.4: {F1_FATHER}: You know, you might feel sad and frustrated about not being good at maths right now, but Iâ€™ve never met someone who studies as hard as you do, {F1_DAUGHTER_16}.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.intro: 6ï¸âƒ£ Here are 6 tips for how you can help Your Teen learn how to cope with their emotions: LEARN, NOTICE, OPEN, TALK, SHARE and CARE
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ LEARN
ğŸ’¡ Learn about different emotions. There are 6 basic emotions, all of which provide us with a very specific message:
ğŸ˜ƒHappy: Keep doing things that make you feel good.
ğŸ˜”Sad: Something important in your life needs attention.
ğŸ”´Angry: Stand up for ourselves and set limits.
ğŸ˜£Disgusted: Move away from what we don't like.
ğŸ‘€Surprised: Stop and pay attention for a moment.
ğŸš©Afraid: Run away from danger.
ğŸ¨ As teens, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ NOTICE
ğŸ‘€ Begin observing these 6 emotions in yourself and in Your Teen.
ğŸ˜ƒğŸ˜’ğŸ˜”ğŸ˜£Notice how each emotion feels in your body.
 
ğŸ˜ƒ You can also notice pleasant emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness.
ğŸ’™ Noticing can also allow your teen to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ OPEN
Be open, notice ğŸ‘€, and listen ğŸ‘‚ to Your Teen when they share how they are feeling. 
ğŸ’› Accept how you and Your Teen feel. Remember your and their bodies are sending messages about what you both are feeling. Recognize that feelings are important for both.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.4.text:
4ï¸âƒ£TALK

ğŸ˜’ It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. 

ğŸ“ Remember, it is also normal to experience feelings in different ways.

â­ When Your Teen is feeling an emotion, describe what you are observing in a calm way. For example, 
â€œI notice youâ€™re pacing around the house, talking loudly, and your face looks a bit upset. Are you feeling angry because you canâ€™t go out at night?â€
You can also help Your Teen learn different emotions by using facial expressions and physical movements. Make it into a game
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.5.text:
5ï¸âƒ£ SHARE

ğŸ˜ƒ Share your own feelings with Your Teen. 

For example, I would feel the same way if I couldnâ€™t go out when I wanted to. 

 ğŸˆThis sets a good example and shows Your Teen that it's okay to share their own feelings.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.6.text:
6ï¸âƒ£CARE

ğŸŒ· Use physical and verbal support to make Your Teen feel accepted and loved. 

â­ Do some active exercise to shake out anger, give some space to each other or take some deep breaths to calm down. These are some of the ways to deal with your emotions. 

ğŸ’š Remind Your Teen that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

Improve My Relationship with My Teen.introduction.msg_list: This skill is about how we can keep calm and manage our anger when dealing with stressful moments with our teens. ğŸ’š
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.importance.msg_list:
As you began noticing feelings, you would have noticed feelings of anger, frustration or sadness. 

ğŸŒ· We love our teens, but stress from caregiving and other events can make us feel angry. This is a normal part of life! 

ğŸ’¡ It is important for us to stay in control and manage our anger so we do not hurt others.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.quiz.content.1.question: True or False: When I am angry at my teen, I should show that I am angry so that they stop misbehaving.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.quiz.content.1.feedback_correct:
ğŸ‰ Thatâ€™s correct! 

ğŸ’› It can be very difficult when your teen is misbehaving, but you should try to manage your own stress and control your own anger before doing anything. 

ğŸŒ± Taking deep breaths will help. Being angry may cause you to say or do things you will later regret.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.quiz.content.1.feedback_incorrect:
ğŸ‘€ Oops! Good Try!

ğŸ’› It can be very difficult when your teen is misbehaving, but you should try to manage your own stress and regulate your own anger before doing anything. 

ğŸŒ± Taking deep breaths will help. Being angry may cause you to say or do things you will later regret.

Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.intro: There are four steps to keeping calm in stressful situations: BE CALM, QUICK, CLEAR, and POSITIVE.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ *BE CALM*

âœ… Be aware of your own feelings.

âœ…Take care of your emotions.

âœ…Remember your goal: make Your Teen feel loved and secure.

âœ…Act effectively: Take a pause or a few breaths before asking Your Teen to do something else.

âœ… Speak with Your Teen in a calm voice.
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ *BE QUICK*

â° There are other things you can do to help manage unwanted behaviour before it becomes stressful. 

âœ¨Praise something positive that your teen did today. 

âœ¨Understand their feelings. For example, it may feel boring to clean up after having fun or ending a big task. 

âœ¨Ask your teen to do something else, and distract them before the unwanted behaviour begins or gets worse. 

âœ¨Invite Your Teen in a chore you are doing. You can ask Your Teen to think of a fun and quick way of doing the chores differently. 

ğŸ’¡ This is much easier than using consequences after they do something!
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ *BE CLEAR*

âœ… Rather than saying what you DONâ€™T want, tell your teen what you DO want them to do.

For example, say:

âœ¨ â€œPlease speak more softly.â€

âœ¨ â€œRemember to hang your jacket in your closet, please.â€ 

This way, it is easier for them to follow! â­
Improve My Relationship with My Teen.tips.message.4.text:
4ï¸âƒ£ *BE POSITIVE*

âœ… Praise your teen when they behave well!

âœ… Redirecting your teen to a positive behaviour will help you manage the situation.

âœ… It will also help them know what you expect from them!

Teen Health and Safety.tips.intro: ğŸ’šIn a dangerous situation, we may not know what to do and freeze or respond in an angry way â€“ this is normal. These tools can help keep your teen be safe: **KNOW IT, SEE IT, SAY IT**
Teen Health and Safety.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ **KNOW IT**

ğŸš© Know the difference between healthy and unhealthy relationships. 

ğŸ’š If your teen is attacked, they should know that it is never their fault. 

â­ Your teen should be allowed to say and do what is needed to stay safe and get away â€“ do not worry about what others may think. They are worth being defended. They should feel they are strong and powerful.
Teen Health and Safety.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ **SEE IT**

âœ…When someone makes Your Teen feel uncomfortable with what they say or do, that is never okay! We all have the right to feel safe, especially at home, in school, and in your community. 

ğŸ’™ Tell Your Teen to follow their intuition. When Your Teen feels attacked with words or actions, the goal is to get away.
Teen Health and Safety.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ **SAY IT**

ğŸ’¡ Tell Your Teen that their voice can stop many attacks. Yell "No!", call for help, warn of consequences, name the behaviour, act crazy, pretend to go along to buy time, or calm them down. 

â­Tell Your Teen to be clear, confident, and direct. 

ğŸ‘€ They can speak using their voice or body language, and maintain eye contact while speaking. 

âœ…Tell Your Teen that they can always tell you or an adult they trust what happened so they can support Your Teen.
Teen Health and Safety.tips.message.4.text: If Your Teen does get hurt by someone, remember it is never their fault. Ask someone you trust for help, and make sure Your Teen knows they can tell you anything so you can find a solution together. ğŸ“±Remember that you can write "HELP" to receive resources that can accompany you and support you.

Teen Health and Safety.introduction.msg_list:
This lesson is about learning how to respond to crises when they happen. â—

This lesson talks about sexual abuse. It is normal to feel uncomfortable or upset when talking about sexual abuse. Remember to take a deep breath. If you need, you can also talk to someone you trust for support.
Teen Health and Safety.importance.msg_list: When our teens share something that is very hard or upsetting to them, we need to remember to stay calm, listen, and be open so that they feel supported. ğŸ’›
Teen Health and Safety.comic.intro: Here is an example of supporting your teen, even when something really bad happens.
Teen Health and Safety.comic.text.1: {F2_GRANDFATHER}: "{F2_SON_15} my dear, you look really upset, do you want to tell me what happened?"
Teen Health and Safety.comic.text.2:
{F2_SON_15}: "Itâ€™s my Uncle, heâ€¦ heâ€¦ he touched me."

{F2_GRANDFATHER} (thinking): "Take a deep breath... What does my teen need? He needs me to be calm and listen"

{F2_GRANDFATHER}: "Come and sit down next to me. Take your time, Iâ€™m listening."
Teen Health and Safety.comic.text.3:
{F2_SON_15}: "Itâ€™s true, heâ€¦ heâ€¦ made me do it! He made me have sex with him! I didnâ€™t want to, I swear, and I even said NO, but he told me I would be in trouble."

{F2_GRANDFATHER}: "I believe you my dear, you are so brave. Thank you for sharing this with me. You are not in trouble. This is not your fault."
Teen Health and Safety.comic.text.4:
{F2_SON_15}: "Yesterday when you went to see your friend. He just came and thatâ€™s when it happened."

{F2_GRANDFATHER}: "I understand, I am here to support you, my dear. This is a big thing and we will find a way to get the help we need. Letâ€™s go to the clinic. They will know what  to do to help you.
Teen Health and Safety.comic.text.5:
{F2_SON_15}: "Yesâ€¦ Okayâ€¦ But will you come with me?"

{F2_GRANDFATHER}: "Of course I will. And {F2_SON_15}? Remember this is not your fault. I love you. This is a really hard situation. We will get through this.
Teen Health and Safety.tips.intro: Here are some things you can do to support your teen when they share any instance of sexual abuse. These tips could also be helpful when Your Teen shares other instances of crisis, like being bullied or being robbed,  with you:
Teen Health and Safety.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ **BREATHE: Take a pause**
ğŸŒ± Take a deep breath so you can respond calmly.
ğŸ’› Ask yourself, â€œWhat does my teen need right now?â€
Teen Health and Safety.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ *LISTEN: Ask your teen what is going on **

ğŸ‘‚ Let Your Teen share with you what they need. Avoid criticism.
ğŸ‘€ Notice what they are feeling and tell them what you notice so they feel heard.
ğŸ’™ Tell Your Teen that you are there for them and love them.
Teen Health and Safety.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ **RESPOND: What might help what is going on?**

ğŸ”¶ You might need to help Your Teen talk about their feelings or redirect their focus.

â¡ï¸ You might need to talk about the actions that you or your teen could take to help with what has happened. In case of sexual violence, you and Your Teen need to go to the clinic. 

â¸. Right now, your teen needs you to be there for them with love. Remind them that it is not their fault what other people did to them. 

âœ… Remember, you can always type {HELP} to Crianza con Conciencia + and get information about resources in your community where you may receive help.
Teen Health and Safety.tips.message.4.text:
4ï¸âƒ£ **COMFORT: Be there for Your Teen**
ğŸŒ· It can be hard to see Your Teen feeling upset or confused, but there is a lot you can do to support them.
ğŸ’š They need you to accept them and comfort them when difficult things are going on.
ğŸˆ Remind Your Teen again that you love them and that together, you two will find solutions. Thank them for sharing with you.

Teen Health and Safety.introduction.msg_list:
This lesson is about how to keep Your Teen safe online. 

There is so much to share. We will cover online safety over two lessons. 2ï¸âƒ£
Teen Health and Safety.importance.msg_list: Teens are spending a lot of time online. â°Being connected helps them stay connected with others, feel like they belong, and get support when needed.! ğŸ”‘But there are also some risks and dangers. ğŸš©
Teen Health and Safety.comic.text.1:
{F1_MOTHER}: {F1_SON_17}, have you done your homework?

{F1_SON_17}: Just a minute, I'm finishing this TikTok video.
Teen Health and Safety.comic.text.2:
{F1_MOTHER}: You are a really great dancer! Tell me about why you like it.

{F1_SON_17}: All my friends are on it. I have more than 600 likes and 120 followers.
Teen Health and Safety.comic.text.3: {F1_MOTHER}: Iâ€™m proud of how well you dance, {F1_SON_17}. Letâ€™s talk about staying safe on TikTok. While itâ€™s fun to share with friends, we need to be careful. Some older people might try to talk to teenagers online. Sometimes, they can be dangerous and want to attack young children and teens. These people are called paedophiles.
Teen Health and Safety.comic.text.4: {F1_MOTHER}: Letâ€™s look together online at how we can keep this fun for you and also safe. Look â€“ you can make your account private and control who follows you. So you can accept people you know but not strangers. Can we make a rule together that you can use TikTok but with a private account? I trust you to know who to accept!
Teen Health and Safety.comic.text.5: {F1_MOTHER}: I am proud of you for showing me your account and taking steps to be safe online.
Teen Health and Safety.tips.intro:
Keeping Your Teen safe online is an important step to help them be part of the digital world. ğŸ“±When it comes to online safety, there are four tips to keep in mind: 
LEARN, PROTECT, BUILD HABITS, and BUILD TRUST.

Today, we are learning about LEARN and PROTECT. 
The next lesson will cover BUILD HABITS and BUILD TRUST.
Teen Health and Safety.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ *LEARN** the dangers of being online: 

ğŸš© CONTENT: Your Teen might come across harmful content, such as violence, hateful speech, pornography, or wrong information. This could also include content hating women, people with disabilities, or people following harmful beliefs or agendas that oppose what you want to teach your teens. 

ğŸš© CONTACT: Adults might pretend to be teens and ask for sexual pictures or to meet with your teen through an online platform.

ğŸš© CONDUCT: Sometimes, teens or strangers can say or do hurtful things online.
Teen Health and Safety.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ *PROTECT - Keep your teen safe online*

âœ… Talk to your teen about which apps and websites are safe and which are not. Discuss why!

âœ… Help your teen learn how to make strong passwords to protect their devices.

âœ… Tell Your Teen that they should keep personal information private, including photos or videos of themselves. What goes online stays online!
Teen Health and Safety.video.message:
Keeping Your Teen safe online is an important step to help them be part of the digital world. ğŸ“±

We are going to learn 4ï¸âƒ£ tips to keep Your Teen safe online: 
1ï¸âƒ£ LEARN
2ï¸âƒ£ PROTECT

Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.introduction.msg_list:
When Your Teen doesnâ€™t meet your expectations or misbehaves, itâ€™s normal to feel upset. 

In this lesson, we will learn how to respond to our teen when we feel angry.
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.importance.msg_list:
Anger is an important emotion because it allows us to express ourselves and set boundaries. Instead of ignoring it, we should learn to recognise and handle it in a healthy way.

ğŸŒ±When you manage your anger, you take care of yourself. You listen to your feelings, make better choices, and teach Your Teen how to manage their own anger.
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.quiz.content.1.question: True or False: It is okay to shout and yell at my teen when angry.
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.quiz.content.1.feedback_correct:
ğŸ‰ Great! 

ğŸ¨ Our reactions to difficult situations are affected by our thoughts and feelings, and not just the actions of other people. 

It is okay to feel angry sometimes, but it is important to learn how to respond calmly even when we feel angry.

When we react with anger most of the time, it may cause our teens to feel scared of them, feel stressed, misbehave more or behave aggressively.
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.quiz.content.1.feedback_incorrect:

Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.intro: Dealing with anger is not easy ğŸ˜”. Maybe no one taught us how to manage our emotions and healthily express them.Here are 4ï¸âƒ£tips you can use to manage your anger and communicate better with Your Teen:
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ **NOTICE** 

How does anger feel in your mind and body?

When you are angry, you might feel like your heart is beating fast, you have racing thoughts in your head, your muscles are tense, or your face is feeling hot. You may feel like shouting, saying mean things, punishing, hitting, or breaking things. 

However, it is important to learn how to control your anger so that it does not result in someone getting hurt.
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ **UNDERSTAND**

Try to see what is making you angry. Take a pause or a few deep breaths, and ask yourself, â€œWhy is this situation bothering me so much?â€If you think you can not control your anger and may hurt someone, STOP and walk away from the situation. Allow yourself to calm down before responding. Remember to be kind to yourself and remind yourself that you can handle your emotions and anger without hurting anyone else.
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ **MANAGE** 

If you need to manage your anger before you respond, you can always begin by taking a pause or a few deep breaths. 

If you are feeling more angry, you can distract yourself from some other tasks till the feeling passes away. For example, watching a funny or comforting video. 

If you are feeling very angry, doing something active helps you release your emotions. You can do some quick exercise, scream into a pillow in a private space, or talk to a loved one. 

You may need to try the strategy more than once until you feel less angry.
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.4.text:
4ï¸âƒ£ **COMMUNICATE**

Once you have calmed down, talk to Your Teen about what happened. 

Explain the situation calmly and respectfully. 

Use the tips in this course to talk about household rules, and giving consequences.

Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.intro: 3ï¸âƒ£ Here are three tips on how to help Your Teen follow instructions more often:
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ **BE SPECIFIC**

â­Say the behaviour you want your teen to do. For example: â€œPlease take your shoes off when you come inside, Rosa.â€

ğŸ‘€Use your teenâ€™s name to get their attention. Sit next to them. Get their eye contact.
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ **BE REALISTIC**

â­Make sure that the instruction is something that your teen can do.
 
ğŸ’¡Give one instruction at a time. It can be difficult for your teen to remember many instructions! 

â°If possible, give a transition warning: â€œIn 10 minutes, it will be time for dinner, and for you to clean the table.â€
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ **BE POSITIVE**

â­Use positive words when giving instructions. For example, instead of â€œDonâ€™t shout,â€ say â€œTalk in a quiet voice.â€

ğŸ’¡Give instructions in a firm voice and stay calm. Behave as if you expect your teen to do what you ask.

ğŸ…**Praise, praise, praise!** Make sure you praise your teen immediately when they follow your instructions.

ğŸŒ·Also, be kind to yourself if you forget sometimes. Learning how to give positive instructions is not easy, but it works! ğŸ’™

Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.intro: Here are four simple steps for using consequences when your teen behaves badly:
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ **BE CALM**

âœ… Shouting or hitting our teens only makes things worse. It also teaches them that it is okay to treat others like this when they are upset.

âœ… Take some deep breaths, take a pause, or walk away if you need to.

âœ… Then, respond in a calm, clear way.
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ **BE FAIR**
âœ… Give your teen the option to behave before giving a consequence. For example, say, â€œEither you do your homework now, or you cannot watch your favourite T.V. show tonight.â€
âœ… Talk about consequences for breaking household rules when you set them so Your Teen knows them already.

ğŸ‘‚ Listen to their view.


âœ… Notice if your teen is experiencing a consequence of their action already. If so, you might not need to give them one other consequence.
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ **BE CONSISTENT**

Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.introduction.msg_list: This lesson is about learning how to solve problems with Your Teen. ğŸ‘‚
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.importance.msg_list: As teens get older, they do more by themselves and sometimes act outside of the rules we made to keep them safe. ğŸš— This can cause conflict at home. Learning to solve these problems together can make your teen's behaviour better.

Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.intro: When something happens, take a deep breath. Then, help your teen work on the problem with these 4 steps:
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ **KNOW IT**

âœ… Put the problem into words. Describe the problem as if you are explaining it to a stranger. 

âœ… Talk to your teen about what the problem is. Remember, your teen or you are not the problem. Focus on the situation.
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ **SOLVE IT**

âœ… Together, think of possible solutions to this problem. 

âœ… What could you or Your Teen do differently in this situation in the future?
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ **TRY IT**

âœ… Choose one solution together.

âœ… Try it next time you are in a similar situation.
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.4.text:
4ï¸âƒ£ **TEST IT**

âœ… Ask yourself, â€œDid it work?â€ 

âœ… If yes, great!

âœ… If not, talk to Your Teen about trying another solution for next time. Use the 4 steps of problem-solving with the new solution.

Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.intro: 4ï¸âƒ£ Here are four tips to help you know what your role is as your teen's caregiver and to teach them their role, too.
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ **KNOW YOUR ROLE**

As a caregiver, your role is to make sure Your Teen:
ğŸ”· has enough healthy food,
ğŸ”· has the clothes they need,
ğŸ”· stays safe from harm,
ğŸ”·has opportunities to go to school, 
ğŸ”·has medical attention when sick
ğŸ”· contributes to family needs, like doing chores, 
ğŸ”· learns the traditions and values you wish them to have, such as honesty,
ğŸ”· has opportunities to express themselves, equally for girls and boys
ğŸ”· has opportunities to play, and
ğŸ”· feels loved and supported, no matter what.
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ **TEACH**

Tell Your Teen what their role in the family is. This can include:

ğŸ”¶ doing age-appropriate chores, like helping prepare meals, making their beds, and sorting laundry
ğŸ”¶ cooperating when their caregivers ask something of them
ğŸ”¶ being respectful to others in the family
ğŸ”¶ going to school and doing their homework
ğŸ”¶be part of family decisions
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ **DO AS I DO**

ğŸ‘€ Your Teen will learn from your actions much more than from the words you tell them. They notice more than you might think!

ğŸŒ· Treat your teen and those around you in the way you would want your teen to act: with respect, kindness, patience, and love.

âŒ Shouting at or hitting Your Teen will only teach them to hit others when they are upset.

ğŸ’š Talk to them calmly and set a clear consequence so they learn to be calm with themselves and with others. 

ğŸ’¡If you are feeling intense emotions, like upset or stress, take a pause to care for yourself and then talk with Your Teen.
Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour.tips.message.4.text:
4ï¸âƒ£ **NOTICE**

ğŸ¨ Notice what Your Teen enjoys doing, and help them do more of it. 

âœ¨ If Your Teen feels that their needs and interests are respected, they are more likely to do their chores in the home willingly!

ğŸ… Notice and **praise** your teen when they do the tasks that are their responsibility so they learn what is expected of them. This way, they are more likely to do it again.

âš½ Play games.

1ï¸âƒ£ **SET GOALS**

2ï¸âƒ£ **ASK QUESTIONS**

â“ Encourage Your Teen to ask questions.

ğŸ“Curiosity will help Your Teenâ€™s brain grow!
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ **MAKE CONNECTIONS**

ğŸ“– Ask Your Teen to connect new information to things they already know, such as one of their interests or a topic from school.

ğŸ”‘This develops and promotes deeper thinking and understanding of concepts.

Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.intro: Here are four tips that you can use to help your teen learn from their mistakes:
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ **TALK**

ğŸ‘‚ Create space and time for your teen to talk with you about their life. 

ğŸ’™ If their day was challenging, listen to them and give them space to let them share.

Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ **PRAISE EFFORT**

3ï¸âƒ£ **ALLOW FOR MISTAKES TO HAPPEN**

Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.intro: You can help them build this skill with these tips:

Support My Teenâ€™s Education.introduction.msg_list:
Today, we will learn how to manage stress. Because this is such an important life skill, we will continue it tomorrow, too.

Stress is when you feel worried or tense because things might be difficult.

This can feel like your brain is too full to do anything, and youâ€™re going to burst into tears, yell, or be too exhausted to function.

Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.intro: Here are 4ï¸âƒ£ tips you can use to manage stress:
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.message.1.text: 1ï¸âƒ£ **NOTICE** What are you feeling in your body? When stressed most of the time, you can experience headaches, tiredness, or difficulty sleeping. Check in on your emotions. Stress can make you feel irritable, snap at loved ones, or want to be alone.Take a moment to notice your thoughts. Stress can fill your head with racing, worrying, and negative thoughts.
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£**BE KIND** ğŸ’š When you begin feeling stressed, pause or take a few breaths. 

Say to yourself, â€œItâ€™s OK,â€ because it is OK to feel stressed - everyone does sometimes!

ğŸ Think about what would a loving friend or family member say to you, which we practiced in our lesson on â€œBoosting My Teenâ€™s Confidence.â€
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ **HEALTHY HABITS** Taking care of your physical health will help you manage stress better. 

â¸ Try to get enough sleep every night - at least 7 or 8 hours if possible.ğŸ Eat healthy foods as much as possible and maintain a balanced diet.

ğŸš² Find ways to move your body and get exercise every day. Even 10 minutes can make a difference.
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.message.4.text:
4ï¸âƒ£ **RECHARGE** Take breaks during the day to recharge your energy. Small breaks can help, bit by bit.
Do things that help you relax and feel good, like practicing taking a pause, listening to music, or going for a walk outside.Spend time with friends or family members who care about you. Talking to someone you trust can make you feel better and less stressed.

Support My Teenâ€™s Education.introduction.msg_list:
Itâ€™s common for parents to feel stressed or overwhelmed when you have so much to do every day. 

In this lesson, you will continue learning ways to manage stress by making a plan in advance.
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.importance.msg_list: Creating a plan for when you feel stressed can help you plan for and manage stressful situations when they happen.
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.comic.intro: {F1_FATHER} is feeling stressed with the many things he needs to do. Letâ€™s see how {F1_FATHER} creates a plan:
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.comic.text.1: {F1_FATHER} (thinking): There is so much to do! {F1_SON_5} is sick, and {F1_DAUGHTER_13} needs help for her school project. How will I manage?!

Clean the house. Help {F1_DAUGHTER_13} with her project. Let {F1_SON_5}'s teacher know that he wonâ€™t be coming to class tomorrow.
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.comic.text.4: {F1_FATHER}: Hmm.. this is too much to do. What is most important out of this? Helping my teen is most important. Bills are not due until later this week, and I can clean on some other day.
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.comic.text.5: {F1_FATHER}: Out of this, I need to make sure {F1_SON_5} gets the care he needs, so that is the first thing I will do. Once I am back, Iâ€™ll check in with {F1_DAUGHTER_13} to see what help she needs.
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.comic.text.6:
{F1_FATHER}:  Iâ€™ll spend 10 minutes cleaning the kitchen so Iâ€™m relaxed while making dinner, but Iâ€™ll save more cleaning for another day.  Iâ€™ll make a note for myself to pay the bill tomorrow afternoon so I donâ€™t forget!

{F1_FATHER}: One step at a time. I can do this!
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.intro: Here are 5ï¸âƒ£ tips to help you make a plan when you are feeling stressed because you have too many things to do:
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ **WRITE OR DRAW** 

Grab a piece of paper, a notebook, or anything you can write on, and a pen.

Take a few minutes to jot down or draw out all the things you need to do today or throughout this week.

Make sure to include everything that comes to mind, like grocery shopping, helping your teen with school work, or going to the doctor.
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ **DECIDE**

Look at your list. 

Ask yourself, which tasks are urgent or really important? 

Put a star next to them. 

These are the things you should focus on first to make sure you don't forget anything important.
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ **RANK** 

Of all the tasks you put a star to, which task is the most important or needs to be done first? Give it number 1. 

Then, look at the other tasks on your list and decide which one comes next. Give it number 2. 

Keep going until you have given all the starred tasks a number.
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.message.4.text:
4ï¸âƒ£ **BREAK IT DOWN** 

If your urgent or important task is still making you feel overwhelmed and stressed, it might be too big to do all at once. 

That's okay! You can make it easier by breaking it into smaller steps.

For example, if you need to clean your house. That can seem like a lot to do! But if you break it down, like cleaning one room at a time, it's much easier.

By dividing the task into smaller parts, it's easier to work on and not as overwhelming. You can focus on each small step one at a time, which makes the whole task feel more doable.
Support My Teenâ€™s Education.tips.message.5.text:
5ï¸âƒ£ **ONE STEP AT A TIME** 

Begin with the number one task on your list. 

After you complete it, move to the next one. 

This helps you focus on the most important things first and ensures you don't forget anything.

Every now and then, take a moment to look at your plan. Check if anything has changed or if new things have come up.

Understanding My Teen.tips.intro:
Learning to feel good about oneself is part of growing up and can be challenging for teens and even adults! 
Here are 4ï¸âƒ£ tips on how to help Your Teen think positively about themselves:
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ **ACCEPT YOUR TEEN**

ğŸ‘€ Notice when Your Teen is sharing a negative thought about themselves. 

â˜€ï¸ Accept Your Teen for who they are, including their strengths and weaknesses. Focus on what Your Teen does well instead of always focusing on what you want them to change. 

ğŸŒˆ Remind Your Teen that everyone makes mistakes. As a caregiver, admit your mistakes when you are wrong. This shows Your Teen that they can also accept their mistakes. 

ğŸ‘€ Remember those times when you were a teenager? Think about how you felt and what you went through. It can help you understand your teen better.
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ **WHAT WOULD A FRIEND SAY?**

ğŸ…Ask Your Teen what makes them feel that way and connect with them about what might be making them feel this way. 

ğŸ”” Help Your Teen change the unkind thought into a kind one by asking them to imagine what a supportive friend would say to them in this situation. What would they say to encourage you? 

âœ¨For example, if you said, â€œI am not good enoughâ€, your supportive friend would say, â€œTell me more about why youâ€™re feeling that way. I think youâ€™re doing your best, and that is enough.â€

How we talk to ourselves changes how we feel about ourselves. This is true for Your Teen too!
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ **BE A MODEL**

ğŸ‰ How you talk about yourself can teach Your Teen how to talk about themself. Remember, Your Teen is always learning from you! 

ğŸ”µ Show Your Teen that it is okay to make mistakes and be imperfect in your life. 

Practise changing the unkind thought about yourself to a kind thought. You can also imagine what a supportive friend might say to you. 

ğŸ”¶When you face difficulty, say kind things to yourself in front of Your Teen.
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.4.text:
4ï¸âƒ£ **TIP THE BALANCE**

ğŸ˜ƒYour Teenâ€™s thoughts are like a scale, with pleasant thoughts about themself on one side and unpleasant thoughts about themself on the other side. 

ğŸ˜”Thinking unpleasant thoughts about oneself at times is normal as teens grow up. 

ğŸ‘‘If Your Teen says something unkind or insulting about themselves, ask them what is making them feel that way. Encourage them to think about what a supportive friend might say to them in that situation. 

âœ…By accepting Your Teen, asking questions to understand their perspective, offering support, and being a model, you are helping Your Teenâ€™s balance tip on the side of pleasant thoughts and feelings.

Understanding My Teen.tips.message.1.text:
ğŸ”„ Your Teenâ€™s brain is like a muscle. Just as lifting weights makes muscles stronger, navigating challenges strengthens the brain. 
ğŸŒ±When Your Teen believes they can improve, they are more likely to keep trying, bounce back from setbacks, and work hard to achieve their goals.  Here are 4ï¸âƒ£ tips to learn how to help Your Teen deal with challenges so they can feel hopeful about their future:
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.2.text:
1ï¸âƒ£**EMBRACE CHALLENGES**

Understanding My Teen.tips.message.3.text:
2ï¸âƒ£**LEARN FROM MISTAKES**

Understanding My Teen.tips.message.4.text:
3ï¸âƒ£**PRACTISE, PRACTISE, PRACTISE**ğŸ‘‹ Every time Your Teen faces a challenge, it's like exercise for Your Teenâ€™s brain, helping them grow! It is just like how practising can make you get better at playing an instrument or a new sport. 
ğŸŒ± Encourage Your Teen to face new challenges and support them along the way. ğŸŒ· You can practise a growth mindset in your daily life too, and become stronger!
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.5.text:
4ï¸âƒ£**STAY SUPPORTIVE**â˜€ï¸ As a caregiver, be a source of kindness and understanding for Your Teen, especially when they are struggling. 

â­ Remember, be mindful of Your Teenâ€™s limits when facing a challenge. A gentle push is okay, but it is important to check if Your Teen is feeling motivated. 

ğŸŒˆ When Your Teen feels comfortable sharing their victories and struggles with you, they will be more comfortable creating bigger goals and more persistent at accomplishing them!ğŸˆShow Your Teen that you are there to support them and believe that they can overcome their challenges.
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.6.text: There may be challenges in your or Your Teenâ€™s life that may be out of your control. ğŸ† When Your Teen learns to face challenges and knows that they can ask you for support, they can feel more hopeful about dealing with challenges that are in their control.

Understanding My Teen.introduction.msg_list:
This lesson is about helping our teens with stress. 
Many things can be stressful to your teen: a break-up, stress in your home, being bullied, and exams. These are big life challenges for a teen.
Understanding My Teen.importance.msg_list:
Teensâ€™ brains are still growing. They donâ€™t always have good skills for dealing with stress. 

Some teens feel a lot of stress. In response, they might feel anxious, withdraw from others, or even feel sick. Some teens may respond with violence, self-harm, or by using drugs or alcohol to cope.

You can help your teen cope with their stress by supporting them through it.

Understanding My Teen.quiz.content.1.feedback_correct: Thatâ€™s right. Teens who are stressed experience many symptoms, but playfulness is not one of them.
Understanding My Teen.quiz.content.1.feedback_incorrect: Oops, Check it out! Teens who are stressed experience many symptoms, but playfulness is not one of them.
Understanding My Teen.tips.intro: Here are some tips you can use to help your teen when they are feeling stressed:
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ **NOTICE**

ğŸ‘€ Look for signs that your teen is feeling stressed. Their behaviour will often show when they are stressed. 

ğŸš© They might get angry a lot, want to be alone all the time, be unable to focus, feel tired often, or not feel like doing any work.
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ **TALK**

â“ Let your teen share about what makes them stressed. Try to accept what they say. 

ğŸ˜£ They might feel a lot of stress about something that feels small to us. To them, it might feel huge!

ğŸ’› Let them tell you about what gives them stress without judging them. Sometimes, it is important to simply listen and comfort Your Teen, rather than solve all their problems.
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ **BE THERE**

ğŸ‘‚ Listen to what they say, even if you canâ€™t do anything about it. 

ğŸ’š Tell them it is okay to feel stressed

ğŸ’¡ Help them decide which things are more important to worry about.

ğŸ”‘ Help them take steps to change what is causing their stress where they can.
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.4.text:
4ï¸âƒ£ **COMFORT**

â­ Comfort your teen, be kind to Your Teen and remind them to be kind to themselves.

â° Be patient and give them time to work through their emotions.

ğŸ’¡ If you think it could help, speak to them about what they could do differently next time.

Understanding My Teen.tips.intro: Here are 5ï¸âƒ£ tips on how to manage anxiety:
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.1.text:
**1ï¸âƒ£ KNOW THE SIGNS** 

Anxiety looks different for different teens. Look out for warning signs of when you or Your Teen might require support in managing anxiety:   

ğŸ”´ Strong, lasting worry that makes it hard to do daily things

ğŸ”´ Acting restless, tired, upset, or avoiding school or work
ğŸ”´ Not enjoying things they used to, getting angry easily, or having trouble focusing
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.2.text:
**2ï¸âƒ£ CONNECT TO YOUR SENSES**

If you or Your Teen is feeling overwhelmed, try the 5-4-3-2-1 activity we learned in the comic:

ğŸ‘€ Look around and name 5 things you see.
ğŸŒ·Notice 4 things you can touch.
ğŸ‘‚Listen for 3 sounds.
ğŸ‘ƒSmell 2 scents.
ğŸ…Taste 1 flavour in your mouth.

Connecting with your senses can help you stay calm when you feel overwhelmed.
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.3.text:
**3ï¸âƒ£ EXPLORE YOUR THOUGHTS** 

ğŸ‘‘Take a moment to think about your thoughts. Here are some questions to ask:

Could this worry come true?
Can I do something to prepare?
Is thinking about this helpful?
Am I trying to solve a problem?
Are my thoughts helping or hindering me?

ğŸ”‘Answering these questions can help you or Your Teen manage anxiety and identify any problem that might be causing it.
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.4.text:
**4ï¸âƒ£ PROBLEM SOLVE**

â–¶ï¸ Think of as many ideas as possible to solve the problem that is making you feel anxious. Remember, no idea is too big or small!

âœ… Pick one idea that you think is the best fit for the problem. 

ğŸ”µTry out your chosen idea and see how it goes. Did it help you feel better? Did you find anything difficult?

â° If it didn't work, that's okay. You can try another idea, or give your solution a little more time.

Remember, problem-solving is a skill you can learn more about in the "Manage My Teenâ€™s Behaviour" course.
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.5.text:
**5ï¸âƒ£ ASK FOR HELP**

ğŸ”¶ If you or Your Teen are experiencing some or many of these things, a professional may be able to support them. 

ğŸ”· A professional diagnosis is required to determine if Your Teen is experiencing anxiety. 

ğŸ˜ƒ Remember, you can type {HELP} at the end of the lesson to access resources for support.

Understanding My Teen.tips.intro: Here are 3ï¸âƒ£ tips to help you and Your Teen manage sadness and spot warning signs of depression:
Understanding My Teen.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ **TALK AND LISTEN**
